diagrams.description: Nanotechnology's conceptual foundations began with Richard Feynman's 1959 lecture There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom, envisioning atomic-scale manipulation. The 1970s-80s brought enabling technologies: scanning tunneling microscope invention (STM, 1981, Binnig and Rohrer) and atomic force microscope (AFM, 1986). 1985 saw fullerene (C60) discovery (Kroto, Curl, Smalley). The term nanotechnology was popularized in the 1980s by K. Eric Drexler. The 1990s witnessed carbon nanotube discovery (Iijima, 1991), quantum dot development, and first commercial nanotech products. 1999 launched President Clinton's National Nanotechnology Initiative in the U.S. The 2000s brought graphene isolation (Geim and Novoselov, 2004, Nobel Prize 2010), nanomedicine advances, and nanoelectronics commercialization. The 2010s saw CRISPR combined with nanoparticles, quantum dot displays, DNA origami techniques, and commercial nanocoatings proliferation. The 2020s continue with mRNA vaccines using lipid nanoparticles, quantum computing advances, 2D materials beyond graphene, nanoplastics concerns driving research, sustainable nanotechnology, and AI-designed nanomaterials becoming reality.

timeline
    title The History of Nanotechnology
    section Conceptual Beginnings
        1959 : Richard Feynman's talk "There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom"
        1974 : Norio Taniguchi coins the term "nanotechnology"
    section The 1980s: The Dawn of Nanotechnology
        1981 : Scanning Tunneling Microscope (STM) is invented
        1985 : Buckminsterfullerene (C60) is discovered
        1986 : Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) is invented
    section The 1990s: The Rise of Nanomaterials
        1991 : Carbon nanotubes are discovered
        1999 : The first nanomedicine is approved for use
    section The 2000s: The Nanotechnology Boom
        2000 : The U.S. National Nanotechnology Initiative is launched
        2004 : Graphene is isolated
    section The 2010s: The Age of Applications
        2010s : Nanotechnology in consumer products (e.g., sunscreens, coatings)
        2010s : Advancements in nanomedicine and drug delivery
